coredata.dc:title: Point charge versus multipole fields in induced absorption
coredata.dc:creator: Cole, Robert H.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
It is shown that the differences between effects induced by the fields of point charge distributions and by multipole moment approximations to the fields are much less than has sometimes been supposed, the reason being that induced absorption is determined by averages over orientations of the squared field intensities. This provides a stronger basis for multipole moment descriptions, but does not justify neglect of orientation dependent energies and fluctuations.

Dipole moments induced by electric fields of a molecule in its neighbors are important sources of far infrared absorption [1—3] and dielectric polarization [4,5] in non-dipolar as well as dipolar gases and liq- uids. Analyses based on point multipole moments as a description of the charge distribution and external electric field of the inducing molecule have g^ven seemingly very satisfactory interpretations of results for a number of gases, but Davies et al. [6,7] have questioned the propriety of using multipole expan- sions to describe fields at distances of a few Angstroms. They have shown that presumably more realistic point charge models g^ve fields at small dis- tances which are very different from those of leading terms in the multipole expansions, and have inferred that such representations give results which are seri- ously in error, especially for liquids. The pupose of this note is to show that the effects of even large orien- tation dependent differences in field intensities are cancelled to a considerable extent by averaging over orientations- but that other complicating factors need to be considered, especially at higher densities. On averaging over angles these vanish, leaving only much smaller effects of higher order squared terms. These conclusions about consequences of averaging over orientations apply both to expressions for the in- tegrated intensity or dielectric second virial coeffi- cient and to calculations of theoretical spectra from matrix elements of the multipole field operators for allowed rotational transitions. The latter can give val- uable information about multipole moments of higher order than the first nonvanishing one, as the differ- ences in selection rules lead to peak intensities at high- er frequencies for multipole fields of higher order- Thus Bimbaum and Cohen [2] have found that high frequency absorption oftetrahedral molecules in ex- cess of octupole induced absorption profiles [1] can be accounted for by hexadecapolar absorption; simi- larly Weiss and Cole [3] found excess absorptions of mixtures of HC1 and HBr in SFg on the high frequency side of dipole-induced absorption which were satisfac- torily accounted for by quadrupole field induction. The point made here is that in these and other exam- ples one does not see effects attributable to cross terms for the reason just explained. Considerations of this kind justify use of multipole moment descriptions at much shorter distances than would be supposed acceptable on the basis of fluctua- tions before averaging, but one still needs to consider effects of orientation-dependent interaction energies between molecules. The approximation of replacing the proper averages by a sum of pair interac- tions weighted by a pair distribution function, which has been used in discussing absorption in liquids [7,8], megelcts the many body character and the fact that one is dealing with fluctuation effects- The fluctuation aspect of the problem is evident in considering a dis- tribution of nearest neighbors arranged with spherical or cubic symmetry, as the sum SCT, of moments in- duced by a multipole moment of any order greater than zero vanishes by symmetry [4], and there is no absorption at all- This suggests that far infrared ab- sorption in liquids may be more useful as a probe of fluctuation effects and test of relevant theory than as a basis for deducing multipole moments or other descriptions or molecular fields.
